title: Six of Sarah Ferguson's companies winding down
partialText: The move follows further revelations over her friendship with the convicted paedophile Jeffrey Epstein.

title: Royal Mail letters sit undelivered 'for weeks' as parcels prioritised, staff say
partialText: Staff and customers tell the BBC prioritising parcels can mean missed NHS appointments and late payment fines.

title: The tech bros might show more humility in Delhi – but will they make AI any safer?
partialText: As global tech leaders meet Delhi, India hopes to level the playing field for countries outside the US and China.

title: Lloyds boss accepts concern over use of staff data in pay talks
partialText: The bank was criticised for comparing employees' spending habits to the wider public as part of wage negotiations.

title: Brewdog staff 'upset and concerned' by sale plans
partialText: Unite said workers had been left in the dark over their futures after the craft beer firm announced plans to explore new investment.

title: ByteDance to curb AI video app after Disney legal threat
partialText: Videos featuring Spider-Man and other characters which are Disney's intellectual property have gone viral since Seedance's update.

title: Reddit's human content wins amid the AI flood
partialText: Reddit says its human contributors are valued amid an internet awash with AI-generated content.

title: Bedding firm backs down on 'Swift Home' trademark after Taylor Swift appeal
partialText: Swift’s team had flagged similarities between her trademark and the company’s contested design.

title: Could Manchester be a model for the UK to kickstart growth?
partialText: With an annual growth rate of 3.1%, Manchester's economy has performed twice as well as that of the UK as a whole.

title: The £10 tricks I used to make my rented room into a home
partialText: Talented tenants share decor hacks that won't cost you a fortune - or your deposit.

title: Andrew's time as trade envoy should be investigated, says Vince Cable
partialText: The former prince's alleged actions were "totally unacceptable", the ex-business secretary says.

title: Gender pay gap won't close for another 30 years, warns trade unions group
partialText: The average woman employee "effectively works for 47 days of the year for free," according to the Trades Union Congress.

title: Head of Dubai-based ports giant quits after Epstein links revealed
partialText: Sultan Ahmed bin Sulayem’s exit comes after files showed he appears to have exchanged hundreds of emails with Epstein.

title: Amazon's Ring ends deal with surveillance firm after backlash
partialText: A Super Bowl advert had sparked new scrutiny of the smart doorbell company's privacy practices.

title: Andrew facing claim he shared Treasury document with banking contact
partialText: Reports suggest the former prince shared a Treasury document when he was serving as trade envoy.

title: Craft beer maker Brewdog put up for sale
partialText: Consultants Alix Partners have been brought in to oversee the sales process which could lead to the businesses being broken up.

title: Heathrow not crowded but people walk in 'wrong place', says boss
partialText: Chief executive Thomas Woldbye says Europeans and Brits keep "crashing into each other" because they walk on different sides.

title: Hello Kitty designer steps down after 46 years
partialText: Yuko Yamaguchi oversaw the feline character's rise to global icon status.

title: Rain and politics driving up half-term holiday bookings, travel agents say
partialText: The Advantage Travel Partnerships says rain plus the political environment is creating a "powerful psychological need for escape".

title: Inflation eases in US as prices for used cars fall
partialText: Prices rose by 2.4% in the year to January, the latest official figures show, the slowest pace since May.

title: Taylor Swift asks US government to block 'Swift Home' trademark
partialText: Her team argued that a bedding firm's designs showed similarities to her trademarked signature.

title: US antitrust chief resigns amid tensions with Trump officials
partialText: The departure of Gail Slater has raised questions about the White House's approach to policing big mergers and monopolies.

title: Trump eyes Venezuela visit – but obstacles to his oil plan remain
partialText: The US president wants American energy firms to start extracting the crude but they are reluctant.

title: Get a grip: Robotics firms struggle to develop hands
partialText: Developing a durable and affordable hand is one of the biggest challenges in robotics.

title: Who is billionaire Sir Jim Ratcliffe and how did he make his money?
partialText: The industrialist and Manchester United co-owner has apologised over comments he made about immigration.

title: The US economy is growing - so where are all the jobs?
partialText: As hiring rates and job openings drop, some worry a tough job market could be here to stay.

title: The Dutch love four-day working weeks, but are they sustainable?
partialText: The Netherlands has the lowest working hours in Europe, but some say it is harming its economy.

title: Why food fraud persists, even with improving tech
partialText: Even with sophisticated technology it is still difficult to detect fake foods.

title: Netflix and Paramount are battling for Warner Bros. Who is likely to win?
partialText: What to know about the two firms' blockbuster battle to control Warner Bros Discovery.

title: How £50m 'fish disco' could save farmland
partialText: Innovative tech scares fish away from nuclear cooling pipes.

title: Plane makers chase Asia's super-rich with luxe new private jets
partialText: Parts of the aviation industry are shifting towards wealthy customers and selling a more luxurious type of international travel.

title: 'Significant' personal tax allowance rise on cards
partialText: The treasury minister prepares to deliver a budget with a "significant rise" in personal allowances.

title: Spud truck handing out free meals to families
partialText: The truck is supporting those who can not afford meals outside of school term-time.

title: Schools project to understand impact of poverty
partialText: A six-month listening exercise has taken place, giving support and advice to parents.

title: Never mind cod, it's tilapia and chips please
partialText: Two fish and chip shops in Fenland are trying lesser known varieties of fish as cod prices soar.

title: The £10 tricks I used to make my rented room into a home
partialText: Talented tenants share decor hacks that won't cost you a fortune - or your deposit.

title: The real impact of roadworks on the country - and why they're set to get worse
partialText: There is a fine balance between the benefits of improved infrastructure, versus the cost of disruption. Does the country have it right?

title: Why the railways often seem to be in such chaos over Christmas
partialText: Parts of Britain’s rail network will close for engineering work over the festive period - but is that the right time to do it?

title: Budget 2025: What's the best and worst that could happen for Labour?
partialText: Three days in, after a tax U-turn and partial climbdown on workers' rights, Laura Kuenssberg looks at what impact Budget week might have.

title: Has Britain's budget watchdog become too all-powerful?
partialText: Ahead of this week's Budget, some have accused the Office for Budget Responsibility of being a "straitjacket on growth"

title: The curious case of why Poundland is struggling during a cost-of-living crisis
partialText: Why - in an age where so many of us are feeling the financial pinch - are some budget shops on UK high streets having such a tough time?

title: Why you should consider switching bank accounts
partialText: Martin Lewis explains why now might be a good time to think about changing your bank account.

title: Thousands queue as beauty store arrives on island of Ireland
partialText: Almost 2,000 people joined the queue for the opening of a new store in Belfast this morning.

title: The Bottom Line
partialText: Why do private landlords attract so much criticism – and how fair is it?

title: Kids can be the harshest critics…
partialText: The candidates test their story on a group of kids.

title: Should you overpay your mortgage or save?
partialText: Martin Lewis explains.
